title: 110_hr6038
content: The Act may be cited as the "Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2008". Congress finds that various technologies exist to enhance the Federal Government's public alert and warning system, providing benefits such as improved security, notification abilities, geographic targeting, and individual alert requests. A modernized system would enable government officials to deliver timely warnings of disasters, like the tornados and floods in the Midwest in 2008. The Federal Government should modernize its alert and warning system to improve its ability to alert residents of potential hazards under all conditions, such as tornados and floods in the Midwest in 2008. The Federal Government should modernize its alert and warning system to improve its ability to alert residents of potential hazards. This includes integrating a public alert and warning system modernization. The Federal Government is required to modernize the integrated public alert and warning system to ensure timely disaster warnings. This involves implementing and updating the system to alert authorities and the public in disaster-prone areas. The Director is responsible for implementing the public alert and warning system, including assigning the National Continuity Programs Directorate to advise on modernization. Common alerting and warning protocols, standards, and procedures must be established, with the system capable of adapting communications based on location, risks, or user preferences. The public alert and warning system must include capabilities to alert individuals with disabilities and limited English proficiency, conduct training, tests, and exercises, incorporate multiple communication technologies, adapt to future technologies, and provide alerts to the largest portion of the affected population feasible. The public alert and warning system aims to alert individuals with disabilities and limited English proficiency, enhance community preparedness through partnerships, and provide redundant alert mechanisms to reach the maximum number of people. Pilot programs will demonstrate various methods to achieve system requirements. The Director will submit a report to Congress every 6 months on the effectiveness of pilot programs for the public alert and warning system, including recommendations for continuing or making programs permanent. The Director will submit findings and conclusions on pilot programs for the public alert system. An implementation plan must be submitted within 6 months, including a timeline, spending plan, and recommendations for additional authority. $37,000,000 is authorized for this subsection. The Act authorizes $37,000,000 for fiscal year 2009 and additional funds for subsequent years. The Department of Commerce and the Federal Communications Commission's authority is not affected by the Act.
